(Tribute)

3.57 pm

    The Leader of the House (Mr Wong Kan Seng): Mr Speaker, Sir, on behalf of all Members of this House, it is my honour and privilege to congratulate you on your election as Speaker. With your extensive experience as a Member of this House since 1984, and as a Deputy Speaker for 4 1/2 years from January 1989 to June 1993 and as a Minister thereafter, Members have no doubt that Parliamentary proceedings conducted in this Chamber, with you in the Chair, will continue to be in accordance with the best traditions of fairness, decorum and propriety. All of us, Members of this House, pledge to support you and cooperate with you in the discharge of your heavy responsibilities.

    Sir, on behalf of the Ministers and the Members, past and present during his tenure as Speaker, I would like to take this opportunity to pay tribute to Mr Tan Soo Khoon, your distinguished predecessor. [Applause.] Mr Tan had served as Deputy Speaker for nearly 4 years, from March 1985, before he was elected Speaker in the Seventh Parliament, in January 1989.

    In my congratulatory speech at that time, I said that Members had every confidence that Mr Tan would discharge his responsibilities with great distinction. He indeed lived up to our expectations and we were delighted to re-elect him as Speaker for two more terms in the 8th and 9th Parliaments.

    In 1989, on his election as Speaker, Mr Tan had said that "he hoped to maintain the high standards and traditions set by his predecessor (Dr Yeoh Ghim Seng)..

Column: 10

I found myself at times trying to unravel myself from some of the complexities of the rules of procedure." Mr Tan has amply fulfilled his pledge. He indeed upheld the dignity of this House by ensuring that order and decorum were observed. Although not legally trained, I believe he has managed to "unravel himself from some of the complexities of the rules of procedure".

    Under his charge as Speaker, our parliamentary debates and all other business of Parliament, including those of the Select Committees and the Committee of Privileges, proceeded most smoothly, efficiently and effectively. As some would put it, it is "like clock-work". He has guided the proceedings in this Chamber most fairly, always giving every opportunity for Members to speak. Despite some long rambling speeches made from time to time, Mr Tan was always patient in hearing them out. He was also indulgent on some Members who pressed on with repetitive questions even though the questions were already answered. He only interrupted when he thought that enough was enough.

    One of the key achievements during Mr Tan Soo Khoon's tenure as Speaker is the building of this new Parliament House which was officially opened on 4th October 1999. He chaired the Parliament Building Committee, formed in 1993, which planned and built this New Parliament House. He made many study visits to other parliaments and learned from them. As a result, this House has incorporated many upgraded features which will serve Parliamentarians well into the future.

    During his Speakership, Mr Tan also strengthened relations with and enhanced our status among ASEAN, Commonwealth and other Parliaments, through the various parliamentary delegations he led and conferences he attended.

    To bring Parliament closer to the people, Mr Tan initiated the Parliament Internet Homepage in May 1996. Internet-savvy readers, local and overseas, can now know more about our Parliament. In 1998, Mr Tan also set up an Education Department to educate Singaporeans about the

Column: 11

Parliament. Thousands of Singaporeans, including students, have learned more about Parliament as a result of their educational visits to this Parliament complex.

    All of us here deeply appreciate Mr Tan Soo Khoon's distinguished service and achievements in this House. Mr Speaker, Sir, Mr Tan once lamented that someone had asked him why, as the Speaker, he could not speak. Now that he is no longer in the Chair, there would be no such constraint. We certainly look forward to his active participation in the debates of this House.

    Sir, this Parliament now has 84 elected Members and one new Non-Constituency Member. Among the 84 elected Members, 25 of them are new PAP Members of Parliament. May I welcome all of them warmly. My advice to all the new MPs is that they should make the best use of their time in Parliament, speak their minds freely on issues which are important and of concern to Singapore and our people. Let conscience be their guide and contribute actively to the debates in this House. We certainly look forward to their participation in this Chamber.

    Dr Wang Kai Yuen: Mr Speaker, Sir, I join the Leader of the House in extending to you our congratulations on this occasion of your election as Speaker.

    Sir, you and I were amongst the then new Members elected to Parliament in the 1984 General Elections. There are not too many of us left. Soon thereafter, you were inducted into Cabinet and, since then, you have played a pivotal role in policy making as well as providing leadership to our nation. As we get to know you better, we have developed a high regard for your character and integrity. Your contributions all these years as Minister have earned our respect. Your election to this high office today signifies our confidence in you. And for those of us who are involved in sports, we are aware that you were a rugby player during your school

Column: 12

years. You have developed a reputation as someone with broad shoulders, who is dependable and reliable, someone who knows when to block, when to pass and when to run. You have also developed a strong sense of team work and fair play, which you have retained to this day. I am sure you will bring these same attributes to your new capacity as Speaker. I would like to affirm that we will all give you our full support and cooperation.

    Sir, with your indulgence, may I take some time at this juncture to pay tribute to your predecessor, Mr Tan Soo Khoon, who had presided over the proceedings in this House for the past 13 years. When I first entered Parliament, Mr Tan had already earned a reputation for wit and clarity in giving speeches, a reputation well earned as we listened to his speeches as new MPs. His election to the Chair in January 1989 was a loss to the subsequent batches of Members, as they had one less master to learn from. Nonetheless, for those of us who travelled with him on official visits, we could attest that he is a speech maker par excellence. His discourse always puts Singapore in good light in front of Parliamentarians from all over the world. It is also well known that Mr Tan has a great singing voice when he let his hair, or whatever is left of it, down. In fact, at this very moment, the tune of Blue Suede Shoes is ringing right in my ears.

    As Speaker, Mr Tan had presided over the proceedings during his tenure exceedingly well. His grasp of the Standing Orders is complete and thorough. Members who stepped out of line would invariably feel his wrath. Furthermore, his handling of Mr J B Jeyaretnam, the Non-Constituency Member of Parliament, who adopted a belligerent stance in this House, earned our great admiration. When it came to Members trying to catch his eye, Mr Tan had been most fair, giving equal opportunity to everyone, new and old. This is very important to us Backbenchers as a point, no matter how substantial, made a second time, would have lost its impact. We had all, at one time or another, experienced the sharp edge of the knife when he applied the "guillotine" when we rambled

Column: 13

on past our allotted time. However, one could not complain, as Mr Tan applied the knife even-handedly, be it a Backbencher or an office holder. All in all, I think I have the support of this House when I say, "Mr Tan, we will miss you in the Chair."

    It would be amiss for me if I do not touch on Mr Tan's crowning achievement, and it is the construction of this new Parliament Complex. The Leader of the House has already touched on this. New Members should bear in mind when they enjoy the convenience and the comfort of this new complex. As I recall, when the new Parliament Building was first contemplated by the Government, it was indeed a very modest concept. It was Mr Tan who planted the seed that we not only should have one that embodies the principles of freedom and democracy that Singaporeans hold dear but one that is worthy of the achievements of Singapore as a modern nation. Therefore, we were all pleasantly surprised that this piece of prime land was allocated to Parliament for this new complex.

    To ensure that we had the best building possible, Mr Tan led several study trips to overseas parliament buildings to learn about their features as well as their shortcomings. During the construction of the building, Mr Tan was also instrumental in setting the requirements upon which the architect would flesh out the design. He was also tireless in chairing the many meetings of the building committee to ensure that future generations of Singaporeans have a great building that we could be proud of. Even though it is the Government that built this complex, we are nonetheless indebted to Mr Tan for the role he played.

    It would take some time to get used to the fact that Mr Tan is no longer in the Chair, Sir. Looking at the bright side, he is now back on the Backbench and we look forward to hearing from him once again.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I would also like to take this opportunity to extend my congratulations to the two new Deputy Speakers, Mr Chew Heng Ching and Mrs Lim Hwee Hua.

    An hon. Member: You cannot say that, as they have not been elected.

    Dr Wang Kai Yuen: I understand that they have not been elected yet. They are two very able Members who have earned our admiration.

    Sir, as reported in the papers, the Leader of the House is prepared to lift the Whip more often in future. With this change, we would expect that the debate in this House will become more vigorous and robust. We all look forward to lively sessions of the 10th Parliament with you in the Chair.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): Mr Speaker, Sir, I wish to put on record that over the years, Mr Tan Soo Khoon, as Speaker of the House, has won my respect for being fair most of the time, if not all the time. I have served in some Parliamentary Committees and also a Member of some delegations to overseas visits, in which Mr Tan Soo Khoon was the leader. Being a non-PAP Member, I have not felt discriminated, and I think this is important as he was the Speaker.

    Last, but not the least, I did sometimes flout the parliamentary proceedings rules and, of course, I got a public lecture from Mr Tan Soo Khoon. I think sometimes he got pek chet with me - he was irritated - but I realise that he did not take these things personally unto himself. For that, I wish to congratulate him for being professional in his conduct as the Speaker of Parliament.

    Mr Inderjit Singh (Ang Mo Kio): Mr Speaker, Sir, first of all, let me take the opportunity to congratulate you on your appointment as the seventh Speaker of the Singapore Parliament. I have known you for the past 18 years, since 1984, when I served as a grassroots leader in Siglap, the constituency where you first got elected as a Member of Parliament. In fact, it is you who inducted me into politics and subsequently convinced me to stand for election.

    Sir, I have known you to be a fair person willing to listen to all views. Your track

Column: 15

record as an MP and Minister for the past 18 years is testimony of your ability and of what you can achieve, and I am confident that you will once again excel in your new role as Speaker.

    Sir, today, we are seeing a changeover of a very key position and that is of the Speaker of Parliament. Since 1989, for a span of 13 years, our outgoing Speaker, Mr Tan Soo Khoon, had been at the helm and, today, the hon. Mr Tan is handing over the baton, or should I say the Mace, to you. I have known Mr Tan since 1991 when Siglap became part of Bedok GRC. Having interacted with his grassroots leaders, I have heard many good things about Mr Tan. His grassroots and community leaders hold him in very high regard, and they have always spoken of him as a very friendly, people-oriented person. The residents have also considered him a friend to everyone in the constituency he was elected in. And since I got elected into Parliament in 1997, I got to know Mr Tan personally and know him much better, having the privilege of interacting with him in the House and outside the House, especially when we went for a number of overseas parliamentary trips. Although we, Members of this House, seldom had the chance to listen to him because the Speaker seldom has the chance to speak, the few times when he spoke, he did so with very clear and thought-provoking words and, at appropriate times, adding a tinge of humour and wit to keep everyone in good spirits.

    I have always wondered whether the Speaker really listened to our speeches, especially to some of us who have the tendency of making long speeches. I am sure he must have heard the same arguments repeated many times over the many years. While I confirm that he was indeed listening to the speeches that we made when I read the Sunday Times' interview two Sundays ago, in the interview, Mr Tan analysed a number of MPs' speeches and the style of arguments, and I must say that he was right. Now we know that he was listening all along and not sleeping with his eyes

Column: 16

open. But, seriously, many times after each sitting of Parliament, Mr Tan made it a point to stay back and sit around the table in the Members' Room with a number of Members each time to discuss issues. During those sessions, Mr Tan used to discuss the contents of debates and speeches with the Members present and always giving his views and, more importantly, giving pointers to Members, especially to new Members, on how we should handle debates and discussions in the House. His many years of listening to and analysing many arguments have always been a great source of knowledge which I found useful for my future speeches. Talking about pointers, one of the more significant things I remember and cherish of Mr Tan's role as Speaker is his reaching out to the new Members of Parliament. As a first-time MP during the last term, I really appreciated his friendly approach with the new Members, helping us to quickly learn the ropes of being a Member of Parliament, both inside and outside the House. He readily helped, coached and mentored many of us so that we could in a short period of time start making contributions towards the parliamentary process. With his proactive approach of connecting with the new MPs, it made all of us feel very much at home and allowed us to quickly become more effective in doing our jobs as Members of Parliament. Especially for us Backbenchers, we also picked up skills on how to handle a debate and how to make Question Time more effective in getting the answers we were looking for from the Ministers.

    One thing that I also cherish about Mr Tan, as Speaker, is how lively he is outside the House, especially when we go for overseas trips. One can understand the need to be lively, especially after many hours of sitting and listening to speeches. I can safely say that Mr Tan is the liveliest of all the Speakers in the ASEAN Parliaments, and I am sure this is also the opinion of all the ASEAN MPs who attended our yearly AIPO Conference. As Dr Wang mentioned earlier, entertaining everyone with his songs of the 1960s and 70s, we always enjoyed the functions held

Column: 17

after each of his conferences. You have to know your rock-and-roll when you are with Mr Tan on one of his trips. If not, then you have to dance, maybe a Bhangra dance, which I had to do in one of those trips with him. Perhaps singing was the way Mr Tan let off his stress accumulated after listening to many speeches.

    Finally, Sir, I am sure that we are all looking forward to the former Speaker finally speaking up in Parliament during this current term. Now is your chance, Mr Tan, to get back at some of us for the long speeches that we made while you were in the Chair. You have earned the right to make long speeches this time round, although I hope you do not. I personally look forward to seeing you in action to contribute towards the making of a lively Parliament during this term. Now, whenever you have itch to speak, you do not have to hold back, as you did when you were sitting on the Chair. Mr Tan should know all the tricks of how to catch the Speaker's eye, and I am sure he is going to get quite a lot of attention from the new Speaker of the House.

    On behalf of all the former and current Members of this House, I would like to thank Mr Tan for all that he has done for the Singapore Parliament and for Singapore. I am sure all Members will join me in wishing him all the best and success in whatever he chooses to do in the future. Mr Tan, a big thank you for your excellent contributions to the country.

    Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Sir, I would like to join the Leader of the House and the other speakers in congratulating you on your election as the Speaker of this august House. You have been a sportsman, and we have also read and known you as the Minister for Sports, and I am sure the Opposition will be very confident that you shall be a very fair person in dealing with the proceedings in this House.

    Sir, I have read in the papers that your advice to Members is to be "short and sweet" in their speeches, and I can assure you that the Opposition shall do that, no

Column: 18

more six-hour speeches as in the past. So far, anyway, the Opposition has always made their speeches short and sweet. I know you shall be a very efficient and fair Speaker and we shall look forward to more fair debates in this House.

    I also take this opportunity to thank Mr Tan Soo Khoon for his job as Speaker. I had complained once or twice to Mr Tan Soo Khoon that I failed to catch his eye when I put up my hand. But I think he was too busy looking elsewhere. Nevertheless, I have known Mr Tan very well through our official visits to the ASEAN areas, in AIPO conferences, and, as other speakers have said, before we go to these meetings, we have to brush up on our singing, because this is one of the things that he loves to do. I was once caught unawares when he was announcing the Singapore delegates' programme in one of the ASEAN conferences - I believe it was in Bali - and he suddenly called my name to represent Singapore in a singing event. Can you imagine, I have to stand up and sing in front of an international crowd without preparation? Well, this is Mr Tan. But, anyway, we have lots of fun and we come to know each other very well. And I must say that he is not only respected in this House but he is respected in the region as well. Everywhere he went, I noticed that Members of the other Parliaments in the region all respected him. I have got to thank Mr Tan for a job well done.

    Mr Tan Soo Khoon (East Coast): May I join the other Members in congratulating you on your election as Speaker of the House. Sir, I have known you for a long time and I am confident that you will carry out the duties of Speaker with distinction and bring honour to the Chair.

    Sir, I have been the Speaker for the past 13 years and it has been a privilege and an honour to serve. Sir, this is your election, the moment is rightly yours. And although I have expected some words of thanks, I did not foresee the kind of tributes that Members have paid to me a while ago and I am indeed very humbled by what they have said. I think that I would not have

Column: 19

been able to carry out my duties as Speaker for the past 13 years the way I had done if I had not enjoyed the confidence and their trust. It is the Members of this House who have made my job easy by upholding the finest traditions of Parliamentary practices, by upholding decorum and by respecting the rules of the House and the authority of the Chair. For that, I am really grateful.

PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS



    The President: Honourable Members, the last five years have been momentous times for Singapore. The Asian Financial

Column: 24

Crisis overwhelmed many economies in the region. Singapore was not spared. Our economy slowed down as well. Fortunately we pulled through and recovered quickly. Then in 2001 the US economy slowed, the global electronics industry slumped, and we experienced our most severe recession since independence.

    We are now emerging from this recession. But we are not back to the pre-crisis days of steady, high growth. The world has changed. The next few years will present us with the most severe challenges in our nation's history.

EXTERNAL ENVIRONMENT

Tougher Global Competition

    Firstly, we face much tougher competition, because of globalisation. Despite problems in the world economy, globalisation has not let up. In many industries, for example electronics and finance, competition is global. This trend is driven by technology, which is advancing faster than ever.

    Other Asian economies like Japan, Korea, Taiwan and Hong Kong, are pursuing the same opportunities as we are, growing their IT sectors, investing in life sciences and competing for global talent.

    New players are emerging in the world economy. As they strengthen their capabilities, they will attract more investments, and export more sophisticated products. They will increasingly compete with countries ahead of them, including Singapore.

    The most important new player is China. China's low costs, abundant talent, and huge domestic market are attracting MNCs to relocate plants to China. Good quality but cheaper Chinese products are flooding world markets. Adapting to China's emergence and economic transformation will pose a major challenge for many Asian countries, including Singapore.

Column: 25



South East Asia

    Secondly, our own region has been fundamentally altered. For three decades, Southeast Asia was stable, with countries focussing on economic development and peaceful competition. Singapore benefited greatly from this benign environment.

    The Asian Financial Crisis changed this. It uncovered serious flaws in the economies which will take time to remedy. Meanwhile, growth will be slower, and investment opportunities will be fewer.

    In Indonesia, a country key to the stability of the region, the crisis did not just cause economic damage. It precipitated a collapse of the old order, unleashed tectonic forces in Indonesian society, and set off political changes which are still being worked out.

    Also, the spread of narrow, radical interpretations of Islam in the countries around us, influenced by the worldwide tide of Islamic fundamentalism, will have its effect on our multi-racial, multi-religious society.

    A troubled region, and an ASEAN preoccupied with internal problems, mean fewer growth opportunities for Singapore in the region. And security problems that arise in the region will inevitably spill over to Singapore.

Global Terrorism

    A third significant external development is the war against terrorism. The Taleban and Al Qaeda may have been routed in Afghanistan, but global terrorism is far from defeated. Terrorist cells, linked to global networks, exist in many countries, including in Southeast Asia. The Jemaah Islamiyah terrorist group is a stark reminder that these are not faraway problems, but immediate threats to us here and now.

    The danger to us is two-fold. Firstly, we are directly at risk of terrorist attacks, especially by Islamic extremist groups

Column: 26

originating elsewhere in the region. Such attacks will cause suspicion and arouse enmity between our races. Secondly, US action against global terrorism may cause repercussions in Muslim countries, and complicate the situation in Southeast Asia.

CHALLENGES FOR SINGAPORE

    This is the new environment that we are now in. Our future depends on how we respond to these economic, social and political changes.

Economic Restructuring

    We must make basic changes to our economy, to stay competitive in an economically changed world, and continue to prosper. Hence we set up the Economic Review Committee to examine fundamentally all our economic policies, and propose fresh strategies to sustain growth and prosperity.

    The Committee is in the midst of its work. But it is clear already that one key priority is to maintain a highly conducive overall business environment. For example, our infrastructure must be first-class but their costs kept competitive, to anchor businesses here and keep Singapore a regional hub. And we must encourage effort and enterprise, as the best way of creating jobs and improving the livelihoods of Singaporeans. Our taxes must be kept as light as possible, to maximise the incentive for businesses and individuals to venture and work hard in the hope of doing well.

    Another priority is to strengthen the spirit of entrepreneurship and risk taking among Singaporeans as the basis for Singapore's future competitiveness. We should inculcate in the young a more inquiring and adventurous spirit, and encourage them to think up new ideas and create new opportunities. Developing arts, sports and a stronger civic society are part of the process to bring this about.

    Entrepreneurs not only create jobs and wealth. They make our whole economy

Column: 27

more dynamic and vibrant, and help us adapt to changed conditions and exploit new opportunities. Strong local enterprises, both start-ups and established companies, will complement the MNCs and add depth to our economy.

    We must also identify new areas of growth, especially in services. We have already started liberalising the services industry, notably the telecommunications and financial sectors. We must also upgrade sectors like retail and construction, whose productivity is lagging behind. We cannot afford to shelter inefficient, protected sectors in our economy. All parts of our economy must become competitive and efficient, for that is the only way to create productive, well-paying jobs for our people.

    These changes will enable us to sustain growth over the next decade. But the competition is now much tougher, and our income levels are much higher than before. We can no longer expect to grow by 8 to 10%, year after year, as we did before the Asian Financial Crisis, even if we were to work as hard as or harder than before. That phase of our economic development is over. Going forward, if we can make 4 to 6% growth per year, we will be doing well. We must understand and accept this reality.

Social Cohesion

    As we upgrade our economy, we must maintain and strengthen our social cohesion. Economic restructuring means adjustments and dislocation. It will not be easy for Singaporeans to cope with the faster pace of change, and the demands for new skills. But we must press on, or risk being overtaken by our competitors.

    Our income distribution will stretch out. In the globalised economy, the rewards are greatest for those with the knowledge, skills and enterprise. Those at the top will do very well. But at the lower end, those without skills will have difficulty raising their incomes, or even finding jobs. This is already happening.

    We should celebrate Singaporeans who do well. By their success, they will create more jobs, build up our economy, and provide role models for others. But to uplift the whole population, we must redouble our emphasis on education and training. Workers must stay employable, and find new jobs when their old jobs become obsolete. They must make the effort, to undergo retraining and to adapt to the changed job market. We must never allow an underclass to form, left out from growth, deprived of opportunities, and perpetuating poverty and despair from generation to generation.

    The Government will help Singaporeans to make the changes, especially those groups who will have difficulty adapting, such as older citizens. We have the programmes and the resources to do so.

    We have spread the fruits of Singapore's progress widely, through HDB home ownership, excellent schools, good health care, and asset enhancement schemes. We will continue to do this, to make sure that in the next phase, life improves for all Singaporeans.

    Next, we must attract and integrate international talent into our society. Talent is the critical success factor in the knowledge economy. We will continue to develop the abilities and skills of young Singaporeans to the full. Without capable and enterprising Singaporeans, we will not make it in the knowledge economy. But we are too small to produce, by ourselves, all the talent that we need. Even the developed countries are now actively sourcing for international talent, including from our part of the world. We must supplement our own talent with talent from abroad. Only then can we sustain exceptional performance as an economy and a country.

    Because of our success in attracting talent, a significant proportion of Singaporeans are first generation immigrants. These people bring with them skills, experience and drive which will enrich and strengthen us. They are, however, different from Singaporeans who have

Column: 29

grown up, studied and worked here for many years. Our society must be open and welcoming to newcomers. We must make them feel at home and in time absorb them as one of us. We must not allow resentment and tensions to build up against newcomers. In the globalised economy, a closed and xenophobic society will not prosper.

    The third and most critical aspect of social cohesion is reinforcing our racial and religious harmony. We have made steady progress integrating the different races and religions, but the task is never complete. The tendency for different groups, with different customs and religious affinities, to interact and seek comfort amongst themselves will always be present. Given today's heightened religious consciousness, we must move beyond mere tolerance, in order to enhance appreciation and build confidence amongst the different groups. We must re-double our efforts to encourage more mixing and interaction between the communities, and gradually widen the common ground that all Singaporeans share.

    The Government will maintain its impartial, secular approach to managing religious diversity. We will protect the minority communities, their cultures and their ways of life. At the same time, all groups must be willing to adjust and compromise, in order to live harmoniously in a multi-racial, multi-religious society.

    The Jemaah Islamiyah arrests highlighted the fault lines in our society. Had the group succeeded in setting off multiple bombs in Singapore, it would not only have cost many innocent Singaporean lives. It would have caused distrust and enmity between Muslims and other Singaporeans, and torn our social fabric apart.

    The Jemaah Islamiyah group has been broken up, but the problem has not gone away. The virus of terrorism has infected our region. Other groups will form, and at some time, will try again. This is why we

Column: 30

must strengthen inter-ethnic relations, for example, by forming Inter-Racial Confidence Circles and Harmony Circles. We must make sure that should such an attack ever occur, leaders of the different communities can work together to contain the damage, re-establish trust and confidence, and prevent further harm to our society.

Political Renewal

    In politics, we must remake our policies to fit a new generation of Singaporeans, and adapt our style and approach to stay in tune with the times. No policy is so cast in stone that it can never be changed, whatever the circumstances. Provided we recognise the realities of survival in Southeast Asia, and remember Singapore's fundamental constraints and vulnerabilities, we can widen the out-of-bounds markers in a realistic and practical way.

    The life experiences of the new generation are quite different from those of their parents. With the benefit of good education, their options are wider, and their expectations higher. This is natural and positive. Each generation strives to give their children a better life and brighter future.

    We must engage young Singaporeans in issues which affect their future. Singaporeans are now better equipped to participate in the national debate, and more ready to discuss sensitive matters in public. We must open up more space for Singaporeans to do so. This is an important way to harness the ideas, idealism and dynamism of the young, while keeping their hearts and minds rooted in Singapore.

    However, more vigorous debate should not lead to more fractious and polarised politics. We enjoy a broad and strong national consensus on the direction which the country should take. This consensus is a major advantage over our competitors. We must nurture it by pursuing policies which benefit the majority of Singaporeans, and by enlisting the energies

Column: 31

and support of all those who have Singapore's interests at heart, including those who disagree with specific Government policies.

    The true test of our nation building is whether Singapore's success endures beyond the founding generation. We have made one successful transition, from the first generation leaders to the second. During the term of this Parliament, we expect to make another political transition. The nucleus of the next generation of political leadership is already in place. Before the next elections in 2007, the core members of the new team must establish themselves, and take Singapore another step forward.

Column: 32



CONCLUSION

    Singapore is at a turning point. The challenges are formidable, but we are well equipped to tackle them. Our system is transparent, efficient and corruption-free. We have pursued forward-looking, rational and prudent policies. We have invested heavily in our people, and built a stable and cohesive society, an oasis in a turbulent region. Let us remake Singapore together, so that despite the difficulties and dangers, we will continue to thrive and prosper in an uncertain world.

External Backdrop



    1. The terrorist attacks on the US on 11 September 2001 and the on-going global anti-terrorist campaign have added a key element of uncertainty to world stability. The end of the Cold War and globalisation have also fundamentally changed the external environment for Singapore. Not only are convenient distinctions between domestic and international interests blurring, but the economic, political and security interests of states can no longer be neatly compartmentalised, instead interacting and overlapping in a complicated manner in a globalised world.

The conduct of Singapore's foreign policy has become an even greater challenge.

Key Foreign Policy Issues For Singapore's Future



    3. Southeast Asia remains in a state of flux following the Asian Financial Crisis. Some countries continue to face daunting political and economic challenges domestically. These difficulties have also provided fertile ground for terrorism and religious extremism to take root, fuelling ethnic conflicts and separatist movements. How countries such as Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines handle these problems will impact the overall security complexion of the region.



    4. Singapore's future is inextricably tied to Southeast Asia. Managing bilateral relations with our neighbours, especially Malaysia and Indonesia, will remain a top priority. Occasional hiccups in our relations with our neighbours are inevitable.     5. At the same time, Singapore remains firmly committed to ASEAN. The perceptions of Southeast Asia's political and economic drift, in contrast to Northeast Asia's dynamism, cannot be brushed aside. ASEAN must reinvent itself and keep pace with global changes. It needs to forge greater internal cohesion and rediscover a new direction. We will work closely with our ASEAN neighbours and Dialogue partners through the Initiative for ASEAN Integration and the Roadmap for the Integration of ASEAN to integrate the newer and older members and ensure that the region remains outward-looking.
